articles.description: Barack Obama played basketball. Bill Clinton and both Bushes liked to go running. Even Donald Trump finds the time to golf. But if you’d like to try something more old-school, here are some of our historical presidents’ favorite workouts. Read more...
articles.title: Work Out Like a President
articles.author: Beth Skwarecki

articles.description: Chinese security personnel physically “skirmished” with a Secret Service agent as well as White House Chief of Staff Ray Kelly last year at Beijing’s Great Hall of the People over the goddamn nuclear football, according to a report in Axios on Sunday. Read mo…
articles.title: Chinese Security Allegedly Wrestled With Secret Service, John Kelly Over Trump's Nuclear Football
articles.author: Tom McKay

articles.description: The National Rifle Association (NRA) hasn’t tweeted since the afternoon of February 14th, the day that 17 people were killed and 15 were injured in a mass shooting at a high school in Parkland, Florida. And it’s kind of strange, because typically the NRA love…
articles.title: NRA Goes Quiet on Twitter, Just Like After Previous Mass Shootings
articles.author: Matt Novak

articles.description: The White House press secretary said that Mr. Trump had spoken to Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, about legislation he helped introduce to revamp background checks.
articles.title: Trump Adds Cautious Support to Changes to Background Checks for Gun Buyers
articles.author: KATIE ROGERS

articles.description: A vigil in Coral Springs, Fla., on Sunday for the victims of the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in nearby Parkland. Students from the school are organizing a demonstration in Washington next month to call for gun control.
articles.title: Donald Trump, Florida, N.B.A. All-Star Game: Your Monday Briefing
articles.author: CHRIS STANFORD

articles.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
articles.title: Asia and Australia Edition: Russia, Iran, Winter Olympics: Your Tuesday Briefing
articles.author: CHARLES McDERMID

articles.description: In the wake of the most recent mass shooting, President Donald Trump sought advice on gun control from a trusted source: rich people staying at his Mar-a-Lago Club in Florida. According to the Washington Post, Trump spent the weekend at his resort watching ca…
articles.title: Donald Trump asks Mar-a-Lago guests what he should do about guns
articles.author: Keith Wagstaff

articles.description: Deli counters of the world — listen up. For as long as I can remember (about two years, since I no longer remember anything before Trump), wraps have been positioned near the apex of the lunch hierarchy. I cannot tell you the number of corporate seminars I've…
articles.title: Why wraps are the lowest form of human lunch
articles.author: Heather Dockray

articles.description: Beyond facilitating a $130,000 payment to silence a porn star, Donald Trump’s lawyer spent years making aggressive behind-the-scenes efforts to protect him.
articles.title: Tools of Trump’s Fixer: Payouts, Intimidation and the Tabloids
articles.author: JIM RUTENBERG, MEGAN TWOHEY, REBECCA R. RUIZ, MIKE McINTIRE and MAGGIE HABERMAN

articles.description: About a dozen people protested against what they called the threat of radical Islam at the Islamic Da’Wah Center in Houston in May 2016. They were met by a much larger crowd of counterprotesters. Both sides, it turned out, were organized by Russian groups.
articles.title: How Unwitting Americans Encountered Russian Operatives Online
articles.author: SCOTT SHANE

articles.description: John F. Kelly, the White House chief of staff, in Florida last week with emergency workers after a gunman killed 17 people at a high school. Mr. Kelly is also facing a crisis in the West Wing after an aide resigned amid spousal abuse allegations.
articles.title: White House Memo: White House Seeks to Move On From Abuse Scandal. But What Did It Learn?
articles.author: MAGGIE HABERMAN and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

articles.description: Victoria McEwen, center, grew up in Sierra Leone, watching her mother help people survive during the civil war there. Now she is among a burgeoning group of African students at Bronx Community College.
articles.title: African Immigrants Find an Open Door at a Bronx College
articles.author: DAVID GONZALEZ

articles.description: Mayor Megan Barry of Nashville at a news conference in January when she apologized for having had an extramarital affair.
articles.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Nashville’s Mayor Has Stumbled. Who Will Cast the First Stone?
articles.author: MARGARET RENKL

articles.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
articles.title: Europe Edition: Russia, Benjamin Netanyahu, Turkey: Your Monday Briefing
articles.author: PATRICK BOEHLER

articles.description: In an interview with "60 Minutes," Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said President Trump's tweets have led him to ask if policy has changed.
articles.title: Tillerson: Trump tweets don't change policy

articles.description: Presidents look back on past precedents (and presidents) perhaps more so than people in most other positions. That's why this President's Day, we're taking a look at some of the things President Donald Trump has said about the men who came before him.
articles.title: Trump's thoughts on other presidents
articles.author: Brenna Williams, CNN

articles.description: As survivors of Wednesday's school shooting demand that it be the last such massacre, marches are being planned around the country to amplify the students' message that action must be taken to end gun violence.
articles.title: Marches planned around US to end gun violence
articles.author: Susannah Cullinane

articles.description: MOSCOW (Reuters) - The Kremlin said on Monday that U.S. charges against 13 Russians and three Russian companies accused of meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential election campaign contained zero proof of Russian state involvement.
articles.title: Kremlin says charges over U.S. election tampering prove nothing
articles.author: Reuters Editorial

articles.description: Secret service teams clashed in November when Chinese agents tried to stop case carrying US nuclear codes from entering Beijing’s Great Hall of the People A skirmish involving the United States “nuclear football” reportedly broke out in Beijing last year just…
articles.title: Chinese and US officials scuffled over 'nuclear football' during 2017 Trump visit – report
articles.author: Tom Phillips in Beijing

articles.description: Some analysts see the ‘petro’ as a desperate move to secure cash amid an economic meltdown brought about by President Nicolás Maduro’s policies Is Venezuela’s new cryptocurrency an ingenious plan to evade U.S. sanctions? Or will it turn out to be a South Amer…
articles.title: Venezuela's new bitcoin: an ingenious plan or worthless cryptocurrency?
articles.author: John Otis in Bogotá
